Woolly Mammoth - I would bring back the Woolly Mammoth as they were one of the most fascinating and intelligent creatures of the Ice Age. They were known to have a complex social structure, with males and females living in different herds. By bringing them back, we could learn more about their behavior, social dynamics, and how they adapted to their environment. Plus, they would be an incredible sight to behold, with their shaggy fur and impressive tusks.

Quagga - The Quagga was a subspecies of zebra that went extinct in the late 19th century due to overhunting. They were unique in that they had a distinctive stripe pattern, with the front half of their body having a brown stripe and the back half having a white stripe. By bringing them back, we could learn more about their behavior, habitat, and how they interacted with other animals in their ecosystem. Plus, they would be a valuable addition to modern zoos and wildlife reserves.

Passenger Pigeon - The Passenger Pigeon was once the most abundant bird species in North America, with an estimated population of 3 billion to 5 billion individuals. However, they went extinct in 1914 due to overhunting and habitat loss. By bringing them back, we could learn more about their behavior, migratory patterns, and how they adapted to their environment. Plus, they would be a fascinating addition to modern birdwatching and conservation efforts.

Thylacine - The Thylacine, also known as the Tasmanian Tiger, was a carnivorous marsupial that went extinct in the early 20th century. They were known to be highly intelligent and adaptable, and were capable of hunting a wide range of prey. By bringing them back, we could learn more about their behavior, habitat, and how they interacted with other animals in their ecosystem. Plus, they would be an exciting addition to modern wildlife reserves and zoos.

Moa - The Moa was a group of large flightless birds that went extinct in New Zealand around the 15th century. They were known to be incredibly large, with some species reaching heights of over 10 feet
